Todo List

Class Element

An alternative for internal value handling is QVariant. Possible advantage: More convenient use, especially regarding value retrieval. The visitor concept of boost::variant requires to introduce funtional objects for accessing or modifying its data. That increases code complexity slightly and is more difficult to read and understand afterwards. The core motivation for boost::variant was to maintain independence from Qt to allow for outsourcing the database code into a separate library (may be useful for other programs too).

Wrap the internal data representation (Element::PropertyVariant) into a separate class. Eventually, the type identification code too (Element::Property and Element::PropertyType).

Class ElementDatabase

Combine single chemical elements and aliases (cfp::Compound) into a single data type. Pro: aliases could be easily visualized in the same way as regular elements. Con: Additional (unused) data fields for ordinary chemical elements (minor) and all the properties of a single element have to be calculated for compounds too: At alias creation time or at access time (major, regarding visualization).

Add a preconfigured list of aliases, similar to http://www.chemcalc.org .

Save user-defined aliases to a file in the users home-directory to restore them after restart of the application.

Class MainWindow
Eventually, rewrite the GUI with python to avoid the hassle with memory management. Keep the backend in C++ (InputData, ElementDatabase).

Global MainWindow::addAlias ()
Remember expand/collapse the state of all cells when raising the add-alias dialog, i.e. calculating the formula (doCalc()).

Global MainWindow::mModel
Check if InputData could be used as QAbstractItemModel.

Global MainWindow::showElementData (const QString &key)
Translate chemical element names when displayed. They appear as regular data entries in the database and are not processed further, atm.
